articles.headline: Home Sweet Home Confinement
articles.snippet: Martha Stewart, released after spending five months in prison, returns to her home in Bedford, NY; Stewart, who is to be fitted with plastic monitoring device for her ankle, must complete five months of home confinement as next part of her sentenc...
articles.abstract: Martha Stewart, released after spending five months in prison, returns to her home in Bedford, NY; Stewart, who is to be fitted with plastic monitoring device for her ankle, must complete five months of home confinement as next part of her sentence; has until Sunday to report to probation officer; probation department will also install transmitter in her house, where she will be confined to single building, almost certainly the main house on her 153-acre property; other restrictions described; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Martha Stewart returned in the early morning hours yesterday to one of her homes, a sprawling model farm in rural Westchester County. And there she found that not much had changed since she last roamed free, with reporters and photographers camped by the dozen in front of her house and the public keenly interested in every detail of her post-prison existence.

articles.headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
articles.snippet: F.D.A. Awaiting More Data On Lung Cancer Drug  Officials of the Food and Drug Administration are awaiting more data before deciding the fate of AstraZeneca's Iressa, a lung cancer drug that was rapidly approved for use by desperate patients but ha...
articles.abstract: F.D.A. Awaiting More Data On Lung Cancer Drug  Officials of the Food and Drug Administration are awaiting more data before deciding the fate of AstraZeneca's Iressa, a lung cancer drug that was rapidly approved for use by desperate patients but has failed to prolong lives in a clinical trial.     The case of Iressa has raised questions about whether the F.D.A.'s accelerated approval program might be allowing ineffective or unsafe drugs on the market. [Page A8.]    Aon Settles With Three States  Aon agreed to pay restitution of $190 million to its customers because top executives of the insurance broker directed transactions that helped mislead customers and possibly increased costs for them, the New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, said. The accusations were made in a complaint filed as the company reached settlements with Connecticut, Illinois and New York. [C3.]    F.D.A. Seizes Glaxo Tablets  The Food and Drug Administration, angered by quality-control problems it said had dragged on for two years, used marshals to seize millions of tablets of the antidepressant Paxil CR and Avandamet, a diabetes medicine, from GlaxoSmithKline plants. [A7.]    Cost of Medicare Raised Again  The Congressional Budget Office raised its estimate of Medicare spending and said the new drug benefit would cost more than it assumed when Congress passed it in 2003. [A14.]    Apple Suing Web Site Publishers  A California judge heard arguments in a lawsuit brought by Apple Computer to force three Web site publishers to reveal the names of sources who disclosed to them Apple's plans for future products. [C4.]    Four Investment Banks Settle  Lehman Brothers, Credit Suisse First Boston, Goldman Sachs and UBS, which helped sell WorldCom bonds to the public two years before the company collapsed, agreed to pay a little more than $100 million to settle with investors who lost money in the deals. [C4.]    Jurors in the government's case against Bernard J. Ebbers, the former chief executive of WorldCom, began deliberations to determine whether he orchestrated an $11 billion fraud that brought down the company in 2002. [C10.]    Management Shake-Up at Delphi  Alan S. Dawes, left, the chief financial officer of Delphi, resigned after the board expressed a ''loss of confidence.'' In addition, Delphi's chief accountant, Paul Free, resigned, and the board demoted the vice president of treasury, John Blahnik, who was also removed as a corporate officer. The management shake-up comes after the company admitted that it had inflated income statements. The scope of the accounting irregularities at Delphi, which are being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission, appears to be wider than the company initially said. [C3.]    Germany Wins G.M. Car Contract  General Motors has decided to build midsize Opels and Saabs in Germany rather than in Sweden because it will cost $262 million less at a time when G.M. is trying to wring $655 million in cost savings a year out of its money-losing European operations. [C3.]    Boeing Suspension Ends  The Air Force ended a 20-month suspension on doing business with the rocket units of Boeing that began when Boeing was found to have improperly obtained proprietary documents and trade secrets from Lockheed Martin. [C2.]    ChoicePoint Faces Several Inquiries  ChoicePoint, the commercial data broker that inadvertently sold tens of thousands of consumer records to thieves masquerading as small business clients, announced that it was the subject of consumer lawsuits, a barrage of inquiries from state attorneys general, and two federal investigations. [C2.]    Nortel Names a President  Gary Daichendt, a former executive vice president at Cisco, was named president and chief operating officer of Nortel Networks. [C10.]
articles.lead_paragraph: F.D.A. Awaiting More Data On Lung Cancer Drug Officials of the Food and Drug Administration are awaiting more data before deciding the fate of AstraZeneca's Iressa, a lung cancer drug that was rapidly approved for use by desperate patients but has failed to prolong lives in a clinical trial.

articles.lead_paragraph: They are just pieces of cardboard, and they cover less than a square foot on the side of railroad tank car. But behind them lies a post-9/11 competition between public safety and national security.

articles.abstract: Take Back Your Time and various advocacy groups say too many workers feel overstressed by demands on their time and are arguing for more paid time off to allow them to devote more time to their families; Democrats plan to introduce bill guaranteeing seven paid days off each year for when workers or children are ill; Pres Bush and allies favor twice-failed bill offering overtime workers choice between  Middle East enters uncharted political and social territory with mixture of anticipation and dread following opening of Egyptian elections to multiple candidates fall of Lebanese government before street demonstrators and limited vote for municipal councils in Saudi Arabia ; uncensored satellite television spurs protests and pressure from Bush administration emboldens them; American campaign for democracy in Middle East is viewed by many as anti-Arab conspiracy; photo (M)

In the previous few days, President Hosni Mubarak opened presidential elections to more than one candidate, and street demonstrators helped topple Lebanon's government.

articles.snippet: Navalady in eastern Sri Lanka, lost at least 620 of about 1,900 inhabitants in tsunami, including wife and four sons of bodybuilder Santosh Chinnathambi Selvam; most of 490 families were related in one way or another; residents waver between vowin...
articles.abstract: Navalady in eastern Sri Lanka, lost at least 620 of about 1,900 inhabitants in tsunami, including wife and four sons of bodybuilder Santosh Chinnathambi Selvam; most of 490 families were related in one way or another; residents waver between vowing never to return and saying they would return if everyone else did; community spirit frayed during refuge at school in Batticaloa, yet according to Hindu custom 30 days after disaster, people returned to Navalady to cook feast for their relatives who had died; photos; map (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: NAVALADY, Sri Lanka - This village had been the loveliest of places to live, sitting on a narrow sandbar that extended into the Indian Ocean like a skeletal finger. On one side was a resort-caliber beach, on the other, a lagoon that separated the village from the nearby town. Palm trees dripping with coconuts provided shade. Water glittered all around.

articles.headline: Gonzo Gone, Rather Going, Watergate Still Here
articles.snippet: Frank Rich column disusses state of network news today; notes recent suicide of Hunter S Thompson and Dan Rather's departure from the CBS anchor chair this week; compares their best work with current state of journalism; discusses case of Jeff Gan...
articles.abstract: Frank Rich column disusses state of network news today; notes recent suicide of Hunter S Thompson and Dan Rather's departure from the CBS anchor chair this week; compares their best work with current state of journalism; discusses case of Jeff Gannon, fake reporter for a fake news organization, who was given White House press credentials; compares lack of investigative reporting today to coverage of Watergate in 1972; photos (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: TWO weeks ago Hunter S. Thompson committed suicide. This week Dan Rather commits ritual suicide, leaving the anchor chair at CBS prematurely as penance for his toxic National Guard story. The two journalists shared little but an abiding distaste -- make that hatred in Thompson's case -- for the Great Satan of 20th-century American politics, Richard Nixon. The best work of both was long behind them. Yet memories of that best work -- not to mention the coincidental timing of their departures -- only accentuate the vacuum in that cultural category we stubbornly insist on calling News.

articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 5 - The new Medicare drug benefit passed a major milestone in recent weeks as a substantial number of big insurance companies said they would offer prescription drug coverage to Medicare beneficiaries next year, defying the predictions of many industry experts.

articles.headline: Rule Change Lets C.I.A. Freely Send Suspects Abroad to Jails
articles.snippet: Classified directive signed by Pres Bush within days of Sept 11, 2001, gives Central Intelligence Agency expansive authority to render or transfer suspected terrorists to foreign countries for interrogation without case-by-case approval as require...
articles.abstract: Classified directive signed by Pres Bush within days of Sept 11, 2001, gives Central Intelligence Agency expansive authority to render or transfer suspected terrorists to foreign countries for interrogation without case-by-case approval as required earlier; process of rendition is under attack from human rights groups, but unnamed CIA official insists CIA has gone to great lengths to ensure suspects are kept under humane conditions; several former detainees describe coercive interrogation and brutal treatment (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 5 - The Bush administration's secret program to transfer suspected terrorists to foreign countries for interrogation has been carried out by the Central Intelligence Agency under broad authority that has allowed it to act without case-by-case approval from the White House or the State or Justice Departments, according to current and former government officials.

articles.headline: Pfizer Stirs Concern With Plans to Sell Heart Drugs Only as Pair
articles.snippet: Some prominent cardiologists object to Pfizer's plan to sell its promising new heart drug torcetrapib only in combination with its cholesterol drug Lipitor; say torcetrapib should be offered as stand-alone pill, so patients can decide whether to t...
articles.abstract: Some prominent cardiologists object to Pfizer's plan to sell its promising new heart drug torcetrapib only in combination with its cholesterol drug Lipitor; say torcetrapib should be offered as stand-alone pill, so patients can decide whether to take it with Lipitor or with similar drugs not from Pfizer that may work better for them; torcetrapib could be one of most promising new heart treatments in decade; it still must clear many hurdles before it is approved; it would not reach market before 2007, at earliest, but already Pfizer's plan is generating controversy; authorities on drug development say Food and Drug Adm may have no choice but to approve combination treatment if it proves more effective at preventing heart disease than Lipitor by itself; say agency has little authority over cost of new drugs or ability to encourage competition among drug companies (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: A drug that could be one of the most promising new heart treatments in a decade is generating controversy even before it is approved, because its maker, Pfizer, plans to sell it only in combination with the company's best-selling cholesterol treatment, Lipitor.

articles.abstract: Aon Inquiry Finds Problems With Personal Insurance  Documents related to an inquiry of the insurance broker Aon provide details of what investigators say were improprieties in personal lines of insurance. Until now, inquiries in the insurance industry have focused on insurance for companies.     Aon channeled home and auto coverage for wealthy Americans to two big insurers, which paid Aon lucrative bonuses and helped pay the salaries of some of its brokers, according to the documents. [C9.]    Interpublic Chief Learns the Game  Michael I. Roth, above, the new chief executive of Interpublic, has never been an advertising executive. He is the first to acknowledge his need to quickly pick up the nuances of how the game is played on Madison Avenue. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C9.]    Plan for a Buyout at Insight  The Carlyle Group and the co-founders of Insight Communications are planning to make a $650 million offer to buy out Insight's public shareholders, executives said. [C9.]    Battles Ahead for Boston Scientific  New research on stents suggests that Boston Scientific, the leader in the market for the devices, will face increasingly tough competition from Johnson & Johnson and Medtronic. [C3.]    Radio Tags Are Costly, Airlines Find  Cash-strapped airlines are having trouble investing in new tracking systems that could reduce problems with lost luggage. [C3.]    A.T.M.'s Pick Up Web Site Tricks  Wells Fargo and other banks are giving their A.T.M.'s a dose of Internet technology. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. [C5.]    Troubles for Small Cars in Crashes  Small cars are not being built well enough to stand up to sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks in side impacts, according to research from a group financed by car insurers. [C2.]    Canadian Beef Ban Causes Trouble  A ban on imports of live cattle from Canada, prompted by fears of mad cow disease, is casting a gloom over the Northwest's beef industry, which depends on imports to fill seasonal shortfalls. [C10.]    Buffett Is Betting on Dollar's Drop  Warren E. Buffett said in Berkshire Hathaway's annual report that he was acting on his view that the dollar would continue to drop. Market Place. [C2.]
articles.lead_paragraph: Aon Inquiry Finds Problems With Personal Insurance Documents related to an inquiry of the insurance broker Aon provide details of what investigators say were improprieties in personal lines of insurance. articles.headline: Many Missteps Tied to Delay in Armor for Troops in Iraq
articles.snippet: Records show that Pentagon's difficulties in shielding troops and their vehicles in Iraq with armor have been far more extensive and intractable than officials have acknowledged, special report, Missing in Action: The Supply Gap in Iraq; finds tha...
articles.abstract: Records show that Pentagon's difficulties in shielding troops and their vehicles in Iraq with armor have been far more extensive and intractable than officials have acknowledged, special report, Missing in Action: The Supply Gap in Iraq; finds that supply problem seen as emergency on ground in Iraq was treated as routine procurement matter back in Washington; among findings: Pentagon's contract for ceramic plate inserts that make vests bulletproof was given to former Army researcher lacking any experience with mass production; Army's equipment manager effectively reduced armor's priority to status of socks; 10,000 plates were lost along way, and rest arrived late; in all, Defense Dept took 167 days just to start getting bulletproof vests to soldiers in Iraq once order was placed; records show it actually took weeks and even months more, at time when Iraqi insurgency was intensifying and American casualties were mounting; by contrast, US allies in Iraq got armor in just 12 days by bypassing Pentagon and ordering directly from manufacturer; photos (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: The war in Iraq was hardly a month old in April 2003 when an Army general in charge of equipping soldiers with protective gear threw the brakes on buying bulletproof vests.

articles.abstract: eBay online auction site reportedly is one of companies most frequently targeted by phishing, form of online fraud in which victims disclose account passwords and other data in response to e-mails that seem to come from legitimate business; company's domination of online auction business and its heavy dependence on e-mail make its users particularly vulnerable to this kind of scam; proliferation of problem means legitimate e-mail that powers eBay deals are increasingly being eliminated by jun
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald Jay Alofs got a call last fall at home asking if he had recently bought several thousand dollars worth of electronics. Mr. Alofs had not, and he had a good reason for not being on a spending spree: he was in the hospital at the time.

articles.headline: Shakeup at Sony Puts Westerner in Leader's Role
articles.snippet: Board of Sony Corp of Japan turns to Westerner to fill top position, naming Sir Howard Stringer its chairman and chief executive; he will succeed Nobuyuki Idei, who plans to retire next year; Stringer is credited with helping revive company's musi...
articles.abstract: Board of Sony Corp of Japan turns to Westerner to fill top position, naming Sir Howard Stringer its chairman and chief executive; he will succeed Nobuyuki Idei, who plans to retire next year; Stringer is credited with helping revive company's music and movie businesses in United States as head of Sony Corp of America; Idei used his background in marketing to reshape Sony into more media-focused company; choice of Stringer to succeed him seen as recognition of turnaround in Sony's entertainment businesses, which are among most profitable parts of company; Stringer hints at future efforts to integrate entertainment and electronics focuses of company; Kunitake Ando is set to resign as Sony's president and be replaced by Ryoji Chubachi; Ken Kutaragi is demoted and will give up his seat on Sony's board; allowing foreigner to take over reins of Sony seen as one of boldest moves Japanese company could make; photo; graphs (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: The board of the Sony Corporation of Japan named Sir Howard Stringer its chairman and chief executive today, an unusual instance of a leading Japanese company turning to a foreigner to fill a top position, the company said in Tokyo.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Saul Hansell

articles.headline: At a Suit's Core: Are Bloggers Reporters, Too?
articles.snippet: Analysis of broader implications for news media should Santa Clara County Judge James Kleinberg rule online commentators and pundits known as bloggers are journalists, with privilege under California law of keeping news sources confidential; case ...
articles.abstract: Analysis of broader implications for news media should Santa Clara County Judge James Kleinberg rule online commentators and pundits known as bloggers are journalists, with privilege under California law of keeping news sources confidential; case involves Apple Computer suit to force Web sites that display leaked product data to disclose identity of Apple employees or contractors who provide data; raises concern that judges may deny reporter shield privilege to all reporters rather than extend it to everyone online (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: In the physical world, being labeled a journalist may confer little prestige and may even evoke some contempt. But being a journalist can also confer certain privileges, like the right to keep sources confidential. And for that reason many bloggers, a scrappy legion of online commentators and pundits, would like to be considered reporters, too.

articles.headline: U.S. Checkpoints Raise Ire in Iraq
articles.snippet: Many apparently innocent Iraqis have been killed or injured at American checkpoints by soldiers wary that second's hesitation can mean death; accounts of incidents vary widely, with American command emphasizing aspects of drivers' behavior that ar...
articles.abstract: Many apparently innocent Iraqis have been killed or injured at American checkpoints by soldiers wary that second's hesitation can mean death; accounts of incidents vary widely, with American command emphasizing aspects of drivers' behavior that aroused legitimate concerns, and survivors saying they were doing nothing threatening; American and Iraqi officials say they have no figures on such casualties, or on far higher number of civilian deaths in fighting that began with American-led invasion nearly two years ago; military says it takes many precautions to ensure safety of civiilans, but refuses to describe engagement rules in detail, citing need to maintain secrecy over how it responds to threat of car bombs; in incident involving Italian journalist Giuliana Sgrena, American military claims it fired warning shots before firing into her car, wounding her and killing Italian intelligence officer; Sgrena claims there was no warning before shots were fired; many Iraqis also tell of being fired on with little or no warning; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 6 - When an Italian journalist was driven up Baghdad's airport road toward an American military checkpoint on Friday night, she was driving into a situation fraught with hazards thousands of Iraqis face every day.
